channel.title: Alerts: Alerts
channel.description: RSS feed for the Alerts list.

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for Victoria Highway near Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling near Victoria Highway in Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley.
Content:

​*Please note changes under bushfire behaviour 

A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling near Victoria Highway in Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley. 

There is no threat to lives or homes but there is smoke across Victoria Highway. 

Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date in case the situation changes.

The fire is burning between Packsaddle Road and Victoria Highway, and is burning towards Victoria Highway. 

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:

 

  • The bushfire is burning in a north westerly direction. 
  • It is contained but not controlled and is burning in inaccessible terrain.

 

 

WHAT TO DO:

 

  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
  • If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears. 
  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222. 

 

 

ROAD CLOSURES:

 

  • Avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.
  • No roads are closed. 
  • Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by calling 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au 

 

 

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:

Approximately 20 Volunteer Fire and Rescue Service, Bush Fire Brigade, Local Government and Parks and Wildlife firefighters are on scene. Firefighters are strengthening containment lines. 

EXTRA INFORMATION:

 

  • The incident was reported at 9.00pm on 8 June 2016.
  • It has burnt approximately 2,000 hectares. 
  • The cause of the fire is unknown.
  • People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Police Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.
  • DFES is managing the fire.

 

 

KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

 

The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow unless the situation changes.

Publication Time: 9/06/2016 3:52 PM
Expiration Time: 10/06/2016 11:00 AM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for Victoria Highway near Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling near Victoria Highway in Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley.
Content:

*Please note changes under bushfire behaviour and extra information


A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling near Victoria Highway in Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley. 

  • There is no threat to lives or homes but there is smoke across Victoria Highway. 
  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date in case the situation changes.
  • The fire is burning between Packsaddle Road and Victoria Highway. 

 

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
  • The bushfire is contained and controlled.

 

WHAT TO DO:
  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
  • If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears. 
  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222. 

 

ROAD CLOSURES:
Avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.
 
No roads are closed. 
    Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by calling 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au 
     
    WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
    Approximately 20 Volunteer Fire and Rescue Service, Bush Fire Brigade, Local Government and Parks and Wildlife firefighters are on scene. Firefighters are mopping up and strengthening containment lines. 
      EXTRA INFORMATION:
      • The incident was reported at 9.00pm on 8 June 2016.
      • It has burnt approximately 3,000 hectares. 
      • The cause of the fire is unknown.
      • People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Police Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.
      • DFES is managing the fire.

       

      KEEP UP TO DATE:
      Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.
       
      The next update will be provided by 4.00pm today unless the situation changes.
      Publication Time: 10/06/2016 11:06 AM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for Victoria Highway near Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE has been issued for people travelling near Victoria Highway in Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley.
Content:

​A bushfire ADVICE has been issued for people travelling near Victoria Highway in Packsaddle in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley. 

  • There is no threat to lives or homes but there is smoke across Victoria Highway. 
  • Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date in case the situation changes.
  • The fire is burning between Packsaddle Road and Victoria Highway, and is burning towards Victoria Highway. 

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:

  • The bushfire is moving fast in a north westerly direction. 
  • It is out of control and unpredictable.

WHAT TO DO:

  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
  • If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears. 
  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222. 

ROAD CLOSURES:

Avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.

No roads are closed. 

Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by calling 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au 

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:

Approximately 20 Volunteer Fire and Rescue Service, Bush Fire Brigade, Local Government and Parks and Wildlife firefighters are on scene. Firefighters are actively fighting the fire and building containment lines. 

EXTRA INFORMATION:

  • The incident was reported at 9.00pm on 8 June 2016.
  • It has burnt approximately 2,000 hectares. 
  • The cause of the fire is unknown.
  • People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Police Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.
DFES is managing the fire.

KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

The next update will be provided by 4pm today unless the situation changes.

Publication Time: 9/06/2016 10:32 AM
Expiration Time: 9/06/2016 3:30 PM

item.title: Cancellation of severe weather warning for parts of the Great Southern
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: ​As at 4.57am on Wednesday the 8 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises the severe weather warning for people in an area south of a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest has been cancelled. This includes people in or near Albany, Esperance and Eucla.
Content:

​As at  4.57am on Wednesday the 8 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises the severe weather warning for people in an area south of a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest has been cancelled.

This includes people in or near Albany, Esperance and Eucla. 

A low pressure system is moving eastwards through the Bight.

Although gusty showers and thunderstorms will continue to affect the southern and Eucla coasts today, damaging winds are no longer expected.   

To date, DFES has received minimal calls for assistance.

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

• If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500

• In a life threatening situation call 000

After a storm SES volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.

FURTHER INFORMATION:

• For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warningsor call 1300 659 213.

• Information about road conditions may be available fromMain Roads WA on 138 138 or visit www.mainroads.wa.gov.au

No further updates will be issued.


Publication Time: 8/06/2016 5:17 AM
Expiration Time: 8/06/2016 5:00 PM

item.title: Continue to take action with bad weather in parts of the Great Southern
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: If you live in an area south of a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest you should continue to take action and stay safe with more bad weather to come this evening and Wednesday. This includes people in, near or between Albany, Esperance and Eucla and surrounding areas.
Content:

Please note changes to warning area and weather details. 


If you live in an area south of a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest you should continue to take action and stay safe with more bad weather to come this evening and Wednesday.   


This includes people in, near or between Albany, Esperance and Eucla and surrounding areas.  

This is unusual weather that could cause damage to homes and make travel dangerous.


WHAT TO DO:   

• If outside find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.

• Close your curtains and blinds, and stay inside away from windows.   

• Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning.   

• If there is flooding, create your own sandbags by using pillow cases filled with sand and place them around doorways to protect your home.   

• If boating, swimming or surfing leave the water.   

IF DRIVING:

• Do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.   

• Slow down, turn your lights on and keep a safe distance from other drivers.   

• Be alert and watch for hazards on the road such as fallen powerlines and loose debris.   

• If it is raining heavily and you cannot see, pull over and park with your hazard lights on until the rain clears.   

• Take care in areas that have been flooded and be careful driving on gravel roads as surfaces will be slippery and muddy, and vehicles could become bogged. 

   

WEATHER DETAILS:

As at 10.45pm on Tuesday 7 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises a low pressure system southeast of Esperance is expected to continue to deepen during Wednesday and gradually move eastwards.

The weather system may cause damaging winds to 100 kilometres per hour that could result in damage to homes and property.  

Damaging winds are possible tonight and early Wednesday morning west of Israelite Bay, and are most likely to be experienced in coastal locations.

Damaging winds  are then expected to extend eastwards into the Eucla district during Wednesday morning.

Higher than normal tides and dangerous surf conditions are possible with the passage of the low pressure system with some beach erosion possible.

 

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

• If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500.

• In a life threatening situation call 000

After a storm State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs. 


KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warnings or call 1300 659 213.


The next update will be provided when the situation changes.

​

Publication Time: 7/06/2016 10:56 PM
Expiration Time: 8/06/2016 4:00 AM

item.title: Continue to take action with bad weather coming in parts of the Great Southern
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: If you live in an area south of a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest you should continue to take action and stay safe with more bad weather to come this evening. This includes people in, near or between Albany, Esperance and Eucla and surrounding areas.
Content:

​*Please note changes to warning area and weather details. 

If you live in an area south of a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest you should continue to take action and stay safe with more bad weather to come this evening.  

This includes people in, near or between Albany, Esperance and Eucla and surrounding areas. 

This is unusual weather that could cause damage to homes and make travel dangerous.

 

WHAT TO DO:  

• If outside find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.

• Close your curtains and blinds, and stay inside away from windows.  

• Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning.  

• If there is flooding, create your own sandbags by using pillow cases filled with sand and place them around doorways to protect your home.  

• If boating, swimming or surfing leave the water.  

IF DRIVING:

• Do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.

• Take care in areas that have been flooded and be careful driving on gravel roads as surfaces will be slippery and muddy, and vehicles could become bogged. 

  

WEATHER DETAILS:

As at 5.19pm on Tuesday 7 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises a low pressure system southeast of Esperance is expected to continue to deepen during Tuesday and gradually move eastwards.

The weather system may cause damaging winds to 100 kilometres per hour that could result in damage to homes and property.  

Damaging winds should develop this evening west of Israelite Bay, and are most likely to be experienced in coastal locations. 

Damaging winds are expected to ease west of Israelite Bay and extend into the Eucla district during Wednesday morning. 

Higher than normal tides and dangerous surf conditions are possible with the passage of the low pressure system with some beach erosion possible.

 

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

• If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500.

• In a life threatening situation call 000

After a storm State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs. 


KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warnings or call 1300 659 213.


The next update will be provided when the situation changes.


Publication Time: 7/06/2016 5:40 PM
Expiration Time: 7/06/2016 10:00 PM

item.title: Continue to take action with bad weather coming in parts of the Great Southern
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest you should continue to take action and stay safe with more bad weather to come.
Content:

*Please note changes to warning area and weather details.  


If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Lake King to Salmon Gums to Balladonia to Forrest you should continue to take action and stay safe with more bad weather to come. 

This includes people in Albany, Esperance, Eucla and surrounding areas. 

This weather is not typical for this time of year and winds could damage homes and make travel dangerous.

 

WHAT TO DO: 

• If outside find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.

• Close your curtains and blinds, and stay inside away from windows. 

• Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning. 

• If there is flooding, create your own sandbags by using pillow cases filled with sand and place them around doorways to protect your home. 

• If boating, swimming or surfing leave the water. 


IF DRIVING:

• Do not drive into water of unknown depth and current. 

• Slow down, turn your lights on and keep a safe distance from other drivers. 

• Be alert and watch for hazards on the road such as fallen powerlines and loose debris. 

• If it is raining heavily and you cannot see, pull over and park with your hazard lights on until the rain clears. 

• Take care in areas that have been flooded and be careful driving on gravel roads as surfaces will be slippery and muddy, and vehicles could become bogged. 


WEATHER DETAILS:

As at 1.47pm on Tuesday 7 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises a low pressure system southeast of Hopetoun is expected to continue to deepen during today and gradually move eastwards.

Damaging winds should develop during the afternoon and evening west of Isrealite Bay, and are most likely to be experienced in exposed coastal locations.

Storms may be accompanied by:

• Damaging winds to 100 kilometres per hour

• Higher than normal tides that may cause flooding of low-lying coastal areas

• Dangerous surf conditions are likely which could cause significant beach erosion.

 

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

• If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500.

After a storm State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs. 


KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warnings or call 1300 659 213.


The next update will be provided when the situation changes.

Publication Time: 7/06/2016 2:08 PM
Expiration Time: 7/06/2016 5:00 PM

item.title: Continue to take action with bad weather coming in parts of the Great Southern
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Lake Grace to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you should take action and stay safe with bad weather to come.
Content:

​*Please note changes to warning area and weather details.  


If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Lake Grace to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you should take action and stay safe with bad weather to come.   

This now includes people in Albany, Esperance and surrounding areas. 

This weather is not unusual for this time of year, but could damage homes and make travel dangerous.  


WHAT TO DO: 

• If outside find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.

• Close your curtains and blinds, and stay inside away from windows. 

• Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning. 

• If there is flooding, create your own sandbags by using pillow cases filled with sand and place them around doorways to protect your home. 

• If boating, swimming or surfing leave the water. 


IF DRIVING:

• Do not drive into water of unknown depth and current. 

• Slow down, turn your lights on and keep a safe distance from other drivers. 

• Be alert and watch for hazards on the road such as fallen powerlines and loose debris. 

• If it is raining heavily and you cannot see, pull over and park with your hazard lights on until the rain clears. 

• Take care in areas that have been flooded and be careful driving on gravel roads as surfaces will be slippery and muddy, and vehicles could become bogged. 

 

WEATHER DETAILS:

As at 11.05am on Tuesday 7 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises a low pressure system is expected to continue to deepen off the south coast during today.

Damaging winds should develop early this afternoon, and are most likely to be experienced in exposed coastal locations.

Storms may be accompanied by:

 

• Damaging winds to 100 kilometres per hour

• Higher than normal tides that may cause flooding of low-lying coastal areas

• Dangerous surf conditions are likely which could cause significant beach erosion.

  

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

• If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500

After a storm State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs. 


KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warnings or call 1300 659 213.


The next update will be provided when the situation changes.

Publication Time: 7/06/2016 11:30 AM
Expiration Time: 7/06/2016 12:00 AM

item.title: Take action with bad weather coming in parts of the Great Southern
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Gnowangerup to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you should take action and stay safe with bad weather to come. This does not include people in Albany
Content:

If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Gnowangerup to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you should take action and stay safe with bad weather to come.  This does not include people in Albany 

This weather is not unusual for this time of year, but could damage homes and make travel dangerous.  

WHAT TO DO: 

  • If outside find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams.
  • Close your curtains and blinds, and stay inside away from windows. 
  • Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephones if there is lightning. 
  • If there is flooding, create your own sandbags by using pillow cases filled with sand and place them around doorways to protect your home. 
  • If boating, swimming or surfing leave the water. 


IF DRIVING:

  • Do not drive into water of unknown depth and current. 
  • Slow down, turn your lights on and keep a safe distance from other drivers. 
  • Be alert and watch for hazards on the road such as fallen powerlines and loose debris. 
  • If it is raining heavily and you cannot see, pull over and park with your hazard lights on until the rain clears. 
  • Take care in areas that have been flooded and be careful driving on gravel roads as surfaces will be slippery and muddy, and vehicles could become bogged. 
     

WEATHER DETAILS:
As at 4.00am on Tuesday 7 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises a low pressure system is expected to rapidly deepen off the south coast during today.

Damaging winds should develop late this morning, and are most likely to be experienced in exposed coastal locations.

Storms may be accompanied by:

  • Damaging winds to 100 kilometres per hour
  • Higher than normal tides that may cause flooding of low-lying coastal areas
  • Dangerous surf conditions are likely which could cause significant beach erosion.

  

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

  • If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500

After a storm State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.
For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warnings or call 1300 659 213.

The next update will be provided when the situation changes.

Publication Time: 7/06/2016 8:46 AM
Expiration Time: 7/06/2016 12:00 AM

item.title: Get ready now for bad weather in parts of the Great Southern
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Gnowangerup to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you need to get ready now for the bad weather coming later this morning. This does not include people in Albany.
Content:

If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Gnowangerup to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you need to get ready now for the bad weather coming later this morning. 

This does not include people in Albany.

This weather is not unusual for this time of year, but could damage homes and make travel dangerous.  

 

WHAT TO DO: 

DFES has these tips to help you and your family get ready now:

• Store or weigh down loose objects around your home like outdoor furniture that could be picked up and thrown by strong winds, causing damage or injury 

• Ensure your emergency kit is complete including a battery operated radio, torch, spare batteries and first aid kit 

• Ensure pets and animals are in a safe area 

• Move vehicles under cover 

• Boat owners should securely moor their boats 

• Campers should find safe shelter away from trees, powerlines, storm water drains and streams 

• Unplug electrical appliances and avoid using landline telephone if there is lightning. 

If you are away from home contact family or friends to prepare your property


WEATHER DETAILS: 

As at 4.00am on Tuesday 7 June 2016 the Bureau of Meteorology advises a low pressure system is expected to rapidly deepen off the south coast during today.

The weather system is likely to cause widespread damaging winds to 100 kilometres per hour that could result in damage to homes and property.

Damaging winds should develop late this morning, and are most likely to be experienced in exposed coastal locations. 

Higher than normal tides may cause flooding of low-lying coastal areas. 

 Dangerous surf conditions are likely which could cause significant beach erosion. 

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

• If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the SES on 132 500 

• In a life threatening situation call 000 

After a storm State Emergency Service (SES) volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs. 

  

KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins. 

For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warnings or call 1300 659 213.


The next update will be provided when the situation changes.

​

Publication Time: 7/06/2016 5:44 AM
Expiration Time: 7/06/2016 12:00 AM

item.title: Prepare now for bad weather in parts of the Great Southern.
item.description:
Category: Storm
Alert Summary: If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Gnowangerup to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you need to prepare your home and family now for the bad weather coming Tuesday morning.
Content:


If you live in an area bounded by a line from Albany to Gnowangerup to Salmon Gums to Esperance and back along the coast to Albany you need to prepare your home and family now for the bad weather coming Tuesday morning. 


This does NOT include people in Esperance and Albany.

This weather is not unusual for this time of year, but could damage homes and make travel dangerous.  

 

WHAT TO DO:
DFES has these tips to help you and your family prepare before the bad weather starts:  

  • Trim branches around your home to prevent them falling on your roof or car.  
  • Clear gutters and downpipes so they do not overflow after heavy rain.  
  • Store or weigh down loose objects around your home or work like outdoor furniture that could be picked up and thrown by strong winds, causing damage or injury.  
  • Prepare an emergency kit with a battery operated radio, torch, spare batteries and first aid kit.  
  • Organise an emergency plan, including a relocation plan for your family and pets in case your home becomes flooded.  


WEATHER DETAILS:
As at 4.25pm on Monday 6 June 2016  the Bureau of Meteorology advises a low pressure system is expected to rapidly deepen off the south coast on Tuesday.

The weather system is likely to cause widespread damaging winds to 100 kilometres per hour that could result in damage to homes and property. 

Damaging winds should develop late Tuesday morning, and are most likely to be experienced in exposed coastal locations.

Higher than normal tides may cause flooding of low-lying coastal areas.

Dangerous surf conditions are likely which could cause significant beach erosion.

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE: 

  • If your home has been badly damaged by a storm, call the State Emergency Service (SES) on 132 500
  • In a life threatening situation call 000


After a storm SES volunteers make temporary repairs to homes that have been badly damaged, such as roofs that have been ripped off or large fallen trees on homes and cars. Please contact your insurance company to organise permanent repairs.  

  

KEEP UP TO DATE:  

Visit www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.  

For the latest weather warnings visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/warnings or call 1300 659 213.  

The next update will be provided when the situation changes. 


Publication Time: 6/06/2016 4:49 PM
Expiration Time: 7/06/2016 4:00 AM

item.title: ​Take care after rising water levels in rivers and streams in parts of the Midwest Gascoyne
item.description:
Category: Flood
Alert Summary: People in parts of the Midwest Gascoyne should take care after rising water levels in local rivers and streams. The Bureau of Meteorology advises the flood watch has been cancelled for the Gascoyne District.
Content:

People in parts of the Midwest Gascoyne should take care after rising water levels in local rivers and streams.

 

The Bureau of Meteorology advises the flood watch has been cancelled for the Gascoyne District.

 

WHAT TO DO:

DFES advises you to:

• Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to act.

• Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous. 

• Do not go near storm drains and pipes, ditches and ravines, as they are dangerous. 

• Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking 

IF DRIVING:

• Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly. 

• Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current. 

• Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged. 

ROAD CLOSURES:

A number of roads have been closed including: 

• North West Coastal Highway closed in both directions from Minlya-ExmouthRoad intersection to Burkett Road, Yannarie.

• Minilya-Exmouth Road in both directions form Learmonth Airport to Exmouth townsite.

Road information may also be available by calling Main Roads WA on 138 138 or visiting http://www.mainroads.wa.gov.au/ 

FLOOD DETAILS: 

As at 9:58 am on Monday 6 June 2016  the Bureau of Meteorology advises the cancellation of the Flood Watch for the Gascoyne District.

No further significant rainfall is forecast for the Gascoyne District for the outlook period.

 

In the absence of significant forecast rainfall, widespread flooding is no longer expected. 

Current river levels are available from the Department of Water at http://www.water.wa.gov.au/ 

WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING:

DFES is monitoring the situation.

IMPORTANT NUMBERS:

• For State Emergency Service (SES) assistance call 132 500 

• In a life threatening situation call 000 

KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit http://www.dfes.wa.gov.au/, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins. 

For the latest flood information call 1300 659 213 or visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/flood. 


No further updates will be issued.


Publication Time: 6/06/2016 10:29 AM
Expiration Time: 6/06/2016 3:00 PM

item.title: Take care after rising water levels in rivers and streams in parts of the Pilbara
item.description:
Category: Flood
Alert Summary: People in western parts of the Pilbara should take care after rising water levels in local rivers and streams. The Bureau of Meteorology advises the flood watch has been cancelled for the Pilbara Districts
Content:

People in western parts of the Pilbara should take care after rising water levels in local rivers and streams.

 
The Bureau of Meteorology advises the flood watch has been cancelled for the Pilbara Districts
 
WHAT TO DO:
DFES advises you to:

  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to act.
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters as they are dangerous.
  • Do not go near storm drains and pipes, ditches and ravines, as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking


IF DRIVING:

  • Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly.
  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged.


ROAD CLOSURES:
A number of roads have been closed including:

  • Nanutarra-Munjina Road in both directions.Closed from Nameless Valley Drive to Munjina


Road information may also be available by calling Main Roads WA on 138 138 or visiting http://www.mainroads.wa.gov.au/ 

FLOOD DETAILS:
As at 9:55 am on Monday 6 June 2016  the Bureau of Meteorology advises the cancellation of the Flood Watch for the Pilbara District.

For the 24 hours to 9am Monday, recorded rainfall was typically less than 25 mm. For the next 24 hours widespread rainfall totals of 15 mm to 30 mm with isolated totals of 50 mm to 70 mm is forecast for the western parts of the Pilbara District.

Though localised flooding may occur from recent observed and forecast rainfall, widespread flooding is not expected in the Pilbara District during next outlook period.

Current river levels are available from the Department of Water at http://www.water.wa.gov.au/ 

WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING:

DFES is monitoring the situation.

IMPORTANT NUMBERS:

  • For State Emergency Service (SES) assistance call 132 500
  • In a life threatening situation call 000


KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit http://www.dfes.wa.gov.au/, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

For the latest flood information call 1300 659 213 or visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/flood.


No further updates will be issued.


Publication Time: 6/06/2016 10:08 AM
Expiration Time: 6/06/2016 5:00 PM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for Parry Lagoons Nature Reserve, 10km south of Wyndham in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: Bushfire ADVICE for Parry Lagoons Nature Reserve, 10km south of Wyndham in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
Content:
The following alert has been issued by the Department of Parks and Wildlife - A bushfire ADVICE remains in place for people in Parry Lagoon Nature Reserve in the vicinity of Parry Creek Road, 10km south of Wyndham in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
 
  • There is no threat to lives or homes but there is a lot of smoke in the area.
  • Although there is no immediate danger, however, there is now smoke impacting on the Victoria Highway, 10km south of Wyndham.
  • The fire started in the vicinity of Parry Creek Road and is burning 10km south of Wyndham.
  • The Department of Parks and Wildlife is working closely with neighbouring landowners who have been notified of the fire.
 
BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
  • The bushfire is moving quickly in a westerly direction.
  • It is is a large and uncontrolled fire.
 
WHAT TO DO:
  • Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
  • Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.
 
IF DRIVING:
  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
  • If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222. 
 
ROAD CLOSURES:
Avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.
 
Road information may also be available by calling Main Roads WA on 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au.
 
RECREATION SITE CLOSURES:
No recreation sites are closed.
 
WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
Fire crews are actively fighting the fire. There is one fire truck and two light units on scene.
 
EXTRA INFORMATION:
  • The fire was reported at 5pm on 3 June 2016.It has burnt 1500ha
  • The cause of the fire is suspicious.
  • People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Police Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.
  • Parks and Wildlife is managing the fire. 
 
KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.dpaw.wa.gov.au,www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow Parks and Wildlife on Twitter @WAParksWildlife or listen to news bulletins. 
 
The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow  (6 June 2016) unless the situation changes. 
 
Publication Time: 5/06/2016 4:37 PM
Expiration Time: 6/06/2016 10:00 AM

item.title: Bushfire ALL CLEAR for Parry Lagoons Nature Reserve, 10km south of Wyndham in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley.
item.description:

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:

EXTRA INFORMATION:

No further updates will be issued.

item.title: Continue to prepare for flooding in parts of the Midwest Gascoyne
item.description:
Category: Flood
Alert Summary: People in the Midwest Gascoyne region should continue to prepare for possible flooding expected during Sunday and into Monday
Content:

​People in the Midwest Gascoyne region should continue to prepare for possible flooding expected during Sunday and into Monday.

There is no immediate danger but you need to keep up to date in case the situation changes.

WHAT TO DO:
DFES advises you to:

  • Prepare to relocate equipment and livestock early so they are not caught in floodwaters.
  • Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for four days, as well as clothing, important documents and medication.
  • Fill your vehicle's fuel tank.
  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to relocate.
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters, as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking.
  • Do not park or camp adjacent to rivers.
IF DRIVING:
  • Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly.
  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged. 
  •  Carry extra food and water when travelling in case of long delays at crossings.
 
ROAD CLOSURES:
Flooding has closed the North West Coastal Hwy (in both directions) from Minilya-Exmouth intersection to Burkett Rd, Yannarie.
Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by calling 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au or local shire.
 
FLOOD DETAILS:
  • As at 10.56am the Bureau of Meteorology advises there is a Flood Watch for parts of the north-west part of Midwest Gascoyne region.
  • Significant river rises with areas of flooding are expected to develop in catchments in the Gascoyne district during Sunday and into Monday.
  • For the 24 hours to  9am Monday widespread rainfall of 15mm to 40mm with isolated totals of up to 100mm is forecast for the north-west Gascoyne District.
  • Likely catchments to be affected include the Lyndon-Minilya and Gascoyne rivers.
  • Current river levels are available from Department of Water at www.water.wa.gov.au.
 
WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING:
DFES is monitoring the situation.
 
IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:
  • For SES assistance call 132 500.
  • In a life threatening situation call 000.
KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit http://www.dfes.wa.gov.au/, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.
 For the latest flood information call 1300 659 213 or visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/flood.
 
The next update will be issued when the situation changes.
Publication Time: 5/06/2016 1:40 PM
Expiration Time: 6/06/2016 9:00 AM

item.title: Continue to prepare for flooding in parts of the Pilbara
item.description:
Category: Flood
Alert Summary: People in western parts of the Pilbara region should continue to prepare for possible flooding expected later on Sunday and into Monday.
Content:

​Continue to prepare for flooding in parts of the Pilbara region

People in western parts of the Pilbara region should continue to prepare for possible flooding expected later on Sunday and into Monday.
There is no immediate danger but you need to keep up to date in case the situation changes.

 

WHAT TO DO:
DFES advises you to: 

 

  • Prepare to relocate equipment and livestock early so they are not caught in floodwaters.  Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for four days, as well as clothing, important documents and medication.
  • Fill your vehicle's fuel tank.  
  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to relocate.  
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters, as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking.
  • Do not park or camp adjacent to rivers.

IF DRIVING:

  • Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly.
  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged. 
  •  Carry extra food and water when travelling in case of long delays at crossings.

ROAD CLOSURES:

Whilst no roads are currently closed there is water over the road from the Minilya - Exmouth Rd (both directions) from Learmonth Airport to the Exmouth townsite.

Road information may also be available from Main Roads WA by calling 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au or the local shire.

FLOOD DETAILS:

  • As at 10.58am the Bureau of Meteorology advises there is a Flood Watch for the western parts of the Pilbara.
  • For the 24 hours to 9am Sunday rainfall totals of 10 mm to 55 mm has been recorded in the western parts of the Pilbara District.
  • For the 24 hours to 9am Monday widespread rainfall totals of 20 mm to 40 mm with isolated totals of 50 mm to 100 mm is forecast for the western parts of the Pilbara District.
  • Significant river rises with areas of flooding are expected to develop in the Lyndon-Minilya rivers, Onslow Coastal Rivers and the Ashburton River catchments in the western parts of the Pilbara during Sunday and into Monday.
  • Current river levels are available from Department of Water at www.water.wa.gov.au.

WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING:

DFES is monitoring the situation.

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

  • For SES assistance call 132 500. 
  •  In a life threatening situation call 000.

KEEP UP TO DATE:

Visit http://www.dfes.wa.gov.au/, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

 For the latest flood information call 1300 659 213 or visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/flood. 

The next update will be issued when the situation changes.

Publication Time: 5/06/2016 1:51 PM
Expiration Time: 6/06/2016 10:00 AM

item.title: Continue to prepare for flooding in parts of the Pilbara region
item.description:
Category: Flood
Alert Summary: People in the western parts of the Pilbara district should continue to prepare for possible flooding expected from Saturday.
Content:

​People in the western parts of the Pilbara district should continue to prepare for possible flooding expected from Saturday. 

There is no immediate danger but you need to keep up to date in case the situation changes.

WHAT TO DO:

DFES advises you to: 

 

  • Prepare to relocate equipment and livestock early so they are not caught in floodwaters. 
  • Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for four days, as well as clothing, important documents and medication. 
  • Fill your vehicle's fuel tank. 
  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to relocate. 
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters, as they are dangerous. 
  • Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking. 
  • Do not park or camp adjacent to rivers.

 

IF DRIVING:

 

  • Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly. 
  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current. 
  • Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged. 
  • Carry extra food and water when travelling in case of long delays at crossings. 

 

 

  ROAD CLOSURES:

Road information may be available from Main Roads WA by calling 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au 

FLOOD DETAILS: 

 As at 10.55 am the Bureau of Meteorology advises there is a Flood Watch for the Pilbara region.

Significant river rises with areas of flooding are expected to develop in catchments in the western parts of the Pilbara over the weekend. 

For the 24 hours to 9am Saturday rainfall of 10 mm to 50 mm has been recorded in the western parts of the Pilbara District.

For the 24 hours to 9am Sunday widespread rainfall totals of 10 mm to 25 mm with isolated totals up to 50 mm is forecast for the western parts of the Pilbara District. Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight Sunday into Monday. 

Catchments likely to be affected include: Lyndon-Minilya Rivers.

Current river levels are available from Department of Water at www.water.wa.gov.au.

WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING:

DFES is monitoring the situation.

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

 

  • For SES assistance call 132 500. 
  • In a life threatening situation call 000. 

 

KEEP UP TO DATE:

 Visit http://www.dfes.wa.gov.au/, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

 For the latest flood information call 1300 659 213 or visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/flood.  

The next update will be issued when the situation changes.

Publication Time: 4/06/2016 12:48 PM
Expiration Time: 5/06/2016 12:00 AM

​People in western and far north western regions of the Midwest Gascoyne should continue to prepare for possible  flooding expected from Saturday.

WHAT TO DO:

  • Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for four days, as well as clothing, important documents and medication.
  • Fill your vehicle's fuel tank.

For the 24 hours to 9am Sunday, widespread rainfall of 15 mm to 25 mm with isolated totals up to 50 mm is forecast for the north-west Gascoyne District.

Further heavy rainfall is expected overnight Sunday into Monday.

item.title: Bushfire advice for Parry Lagoons Nature Reserve, 10km south of Wyndham in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: The following alert has been issued by the Department of Parks and Wildlife - ​A bushfire ADVICE has been issued for people in Parry Lagoon Nature Reserve in the vicinity of Parry Creek Road, 10km south of Wyndham in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley
Content:

​The following alert has been issued by the Department of Parks and Wildlife - A bushfire ADVICE has been issued for people in Parry Lagoon Nature Reserve in the vicinity of Parry Creek Road, 10km south of Wyndham in the Shire of Wyndham East Kimberley

  • There is no threat to lives or homes but there is a lot of smoke in the area
  • Although there is no immediate danger people north of Parry Creek Road should leave the nature reserve
  • The first started in the vicinity of Parry Creek Road and is burning 10km south of Wyndham
  • The Department of Parks and Wildlife is working closely with neighbouring landowners who have been notified of the fire

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:

  • The bushfire is moving quickly in a westerly direction.
  • It is is a large, 1300ha, uncontrolled fire.

WHAT TO DO: 

  • Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
  • Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames. 

IF DRIVING:

  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
  • If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears
  • If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.  

ROAD CLOSURES:
Avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site. 
Road information may also be available by calling Main Roads WA on 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au.

RECREATION SITE CLOSURES:
No recreation sites are closed, however, people north of Parry Creek Road should leave the nature reserve. 

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
Fire crews are monitoring the fire

EXTRA INFORMATION:

  • The fire was reported at 5pm on 3 June 2016.
  • The cause of the fire is suspicious.
  • People are asked to report any suspicious behaviour to Police Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.
  • Parks and Wildlife is managing the fire.

 

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.dpaw.wa.gov.au,www.dfes.wa.gov.au, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow Parks and Wildlife on Twitter @WAParksWildlife or listen to news bulletins.
END 

The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow (5 June 2016) unless the situation changes.

People in western parts of the Pilbara region should continue to prepare for possible flooding expected from today. 

There is no immediate danger but you need to keep up to date in case the situation changes.

WHAT TO DO:

  • Prepare to relocate equipment and livestock early so they are not caught in floodwaters.
  • Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for four days, as well as clothing, important documents and medication.
  • Fill your vehicle's fuel tank.
  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to relocate.
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters, as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking.
  • Do not park or camp adjacent to rivers.

IF DRIVING:

  • Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly.
  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged.
  • Carry extra food and water when travelling in case of long delays at crossings.

ROAD CLOSURES:

Significant stream rises with areas of flooding are expected to develop in the Lyndon-Minilya River catchments over the weekend.

item.title: Prepare for flooding in parts of the Midwest Gascoyne
item.description:
Category: Flood
Alert Summary: People in western and far north western parts of the Midwest Gascoyne should prepare for possible flooding expected from Friday.
Content:

​

People in western and far north western parts of the Midwest Gascoyne should prepare for possible flooding expected from Friday.
 
There is no immediate danger but you need to keep up to date in case the situation changes.
 
WHAT TO DO:
DFES advises you to:
  • Prepare to relocate equipment and livestock early so they are not caught in floodwaters.
  • Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for four days, as well as clothing, important documents and medication.
  • Fill your vehicle''s fuel tank.
  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to relocate.
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters, as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking.
  • Do not park or camp adjacent to rivers.
 
IF DRIVING:
  • Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly.
  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged.
  • Carry extra food and water when travelling in case of long delays at crossings.
 
FLOOD DETAILS:
As at 11.29am on Friday 3 June the Bureau of Meteorology advises there is a Flood Watch for the Gascoyne District.
 
A rain band will affect western parts and far northern western parts of the Gascoyne from late Friday onwards.
 
For the 24 hours to 9am Saturday widespread rainfall of 25 mm to 50 mm with isolated totals up to 80 mm is forecast for the
north western parts of the Gascoyne district.
 
A second period of heavy rainfall will commence during Sunday and areas throughout the Gascoyne district may receive additional rainfall of 25mm to 50mm with isolated totals up to 75mm.
 
Significant river rises and areas of flooding may develop in catchments in the Gascoyne District over the weekend.
 
Catchments likely to be affected include: Lyndon-Minilya, Gascoyne, Wooramel and Murchison Rivers.
 
Current river levels are available from Department of Water at www.water.wa.gov.au.
 
WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING:
DFES is monitoring the situation. 
 
IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:
  • For SES assistance call 132 500.
  • In a life threatening situation call 000.
 
KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit http://www.dfes.wa.gov.au/, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.
 
For the latest flood information call 1300 659 213 or visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/flood. 
 
The next update will be issued when the situation changes.
Publication Time: 3/06/2016 12:05 PM
Expiration Time: 4/06/2016 12:40 PM

item.title: Prepare for flooding in parts of the Pilbara
item.description:
Category: Flood
Alert Summary: People in western parts of the Pilbara region should prepare for possible flooding expected tomorrow.
Content:

People in western parts of the Pilbara region should prepare for possible flooding expected tomorrow. 

There is no immediate danger but you need to keep up to date in case the situation changes.

WHAT TO DO:
DFES advises you to:

  • Prepare to relocate equipment and livestock early so they are not caught in floodwaters.
  • Prepare an emergency kit including enough canned food and water to last for four days, as well as clothing, important documents and medication.
  • Fill your vehicle's fuel tank.
  • Watch for changes in water levels so you are ready if you need to relocate.
  • Never walk, swim or play in floodwaters, as they are dangerous.
  • Stay out of rivers, this includes no swimming or kayaking.
  • Do not park or camp adjacent to rivers.

IF DRIVING:

  • Be careful at crossings and floodways as river levels may rise rapidly.
  • Obey road closure signs and do not drive into water of unknown depth and current.
  • Take care on gravel and unsealed roads as they may be slippery and muddy, and you could get bogged.
  • Carry extra food and water when travelling in case of long delays at crossings.

ROAD CLOSURES:

Road information may be available from Main Roads WA by calling 138 138 or visiting www.mainroads.wa.gov.au 

FLOOD DETAILS: 

As at 2.55pm the Bureau of Meteorology advises there is a Flood Watch for the western parts of the Pilbara. 

Significant stream rises with areas of flooding are expected to develop in the Lyndon-Minilya River catchment from Friday onwards.

Current river levels are available from Department of Water at www.water.wa.gov.au.

WHAT EMERGENCY SERVICES ARE DOING:

DFES is monitoring the situation. 

IF YOU NEED ASSISTANCE:

  • For SES assistance call 132 500.
  • In a life threatening situation call 000.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit http://www.dfes.wa.gov.au/, call 13 DFES (13 3337), follow DFES on Twitter @dfes_wa or listen to news bulletins.

For the latest flood information call 1300 659 213 or visit www.bom.gov.au/wa/flood. 

The next update will be issued when the situation changes.​

Publication Time: 2/06/2016 3:15 PM
Expiration Time: 3/06/2016 11:25 AM
